lessons.title: What is a Computer Keyboard?
lessons.content:
A computer keyboard is an input device used to type letters, numbers, and symbols into a computer. It works like the keyboard on your phone or typewriter, but it has many more keys and functions.

1. What It Does:
The keyboard helps you tell the computer what to do â€” by typing commands, words, or numbers. For example, when you type a message or your name, you use the keyboard.

2. How It Looks:
A keyboard has many buttons called keys, arranged in rows. Most keyboards have between 80 and 110 keys.

3. Fun Fact:
The word â€˜keyboardâ€™ means a board with keys! Without it, it would be very hard to use a computer.

lessons.title: Layout of the Keyboard
lessons.content:
The keyboard layout shows how all the keys are arranged on the keyboard. The most common layout is called the QWERTY layout because the first six letters on the top letter row are Q, W, E, R, T, and Y.

Parts of the Keyboard Layout:
ğŸ‘‰ Typing area â€“ where you find letter, number, and punctuation keys.
ğŸ‘‰ Function keys â€“ the row at the top (F1 to F12) used for special actions.
ğŸ‘‰ Navigation keys â€“ used for moving the cursor (arrows, Home, End).
ğŸ‘‰ Numeric keypad â€“ found on the right side for typing numbers quickly.
ğŸ‘‰ Control keys â€“ like Ctrl, Alt, and Shift for shortcuts.

lessons.title: How to Use the Keyboard for Typing
lessons.content:
Typing is the skill of pressing the right keys quickly and correctly. Good typing skills make computer work faster and easier.

1. Posture for Typing:
âœ… Sit straight on a chair.
âœ… Keep both feet flat on the floor.
âœ… Keep your fingers curved over the keys.
âœ… Donâ€™t bend your wrists too much.

2. Home Row Rule:
Start typing with your fingers on the Home Row Keys â€” A, S, D, F, J, K, L, ;
The left hand controls A, S, D, F and the right hand controls J, K, L, ;

3. Practice:
Use online typing tutors or games to improve your speed and accuracy.

lessons.title: Function Keys (F1â€“F12)
lessons.content:
The Function Keys are the special keys at the top of the keyboard, labeled from F1 to F12. Each key has its own job or command that helps you work faster on the computer. Their functions can change depending on the program you are using.


ğŸ–±ï¸ Hereâ€™s What Each Function Key Does:

  • F1 â€“ Opens the Help window in most programs. (Example: If you are stuck, press F1 for help!)
  • F2 â€“ Used to rename a selected file or folder quickly. Just click on a file and press F2 to change its name.
  • F3 â€“ Opens the search feature in many programs or browsers so you can find things faster.
  • F4 â€“ In Windows, pressing Alt + F4 closes the active window or program. (Use it to quickly close a page!)
  • F5 â€“ Used to refresh or reload a webpage or document. Try it when a page isnâ€™t showing updates.
  • F6 â€“ Moves the cursor to the address bar in most web browsers. Helpful for typing website links quickly.
  • F7 â€“ Opens the spelling and grammar check tool in Microsoft Word and some other writing programs.
  • F8 â€“ Commonly used to access Safe Mode when starting a computer (for troubleshooting).
  • F9 â€“ Refreshes or sends/receives emails in Microsoft Outlook. Also updates formulas in Excel.
  • F10 â€“ Activates the menu bar in many programs. With Shift + F10, it acts like a right-click on a selected item.
  • F11 â€“ Turns the browser into full-screen mode. Press again to return to normal view.
  • F12 â€“ Opens the Save As window in Microsoft Word. You can use it to save a copy of your work quickly.

ğŸ’¡ Extra Tips:

  • You can hold Fn (Function key) with F1â€“F12 on laptops to activate special actions like volume, brightness, or Wi-Fi.
  • Each function key can do different things depending on the software you are using.

In short: Function keys help you work faster and smarter. Try using them to explore shortcuts and make computing fun!

lessons.title: Numeric and Symbol Keys
lessons.content:
Numeric and symbol keys help you enter numbers and special characters.

1. Numeric Keys:
These are the number keys 0â€“9 located above the alphabet keys and also on the numeric keypad.
Example: You use them when typing your age (10) or doing sums (2 + 3).

2. Symbol Keys:
These include signs like ! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + etc. They are typed by holding the Shift key and pressing another key.

3. Uses:
Symbols are used in email addresses, passwords, and mathematics.

lessons.title: Home Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Home Row Keys are the central row of the keyboard where your fingers rest while typing.

ğŸ‘‰ Left hand: A, S, D, F
ğŸ‘‰ Right hand: J, K, L, ;

These are called the home row because your fingers always return here after pressing any key. It helps you type faster and reduces mistakes.

Tip: There are small bumps on F and J keys to help you find them without looking.

lessons.title: Top Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Top Row Keys are located just above the home row and include letters like Q, W, E, R, T, Y, U, I, O, P.

When typing, you move your fingers slightly upward to reach these keys. They are often used in many English words â€” for example, â€˜typeâ€™, â€˜wordâ€™, and â€˜youâ€™.

Fun Fact: The QWERTY layout got its name from the first six letters of this row!

lessons.title: Bottom Row Keys
lessons.content:
The Bottom Row is found below the home row and contains keys such as Z, X, C, V, B, N, M, comma, and period.

This row also includes important keys like Spacebar, Ctrl, Alt, and Windows key.

Tip: The Spacebar key is the longest key and it adds space between words when typing.

lessons.title: Punctuation Keys
lessons.content:
Punctuation keys help you make your sentences clear and correct. They include:

ğŸ‘‰ Colon (:) and semicolon (;)
ğŸ‘‰ Quotation marks (â€˜ â€™ and â€œ â€)

Tip: Use punctuation to show pauses, questions, or excitement in your writing.

lessons.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
lessons.content:
Keyboard shortcuts are special key combinations that help you perform tasks quickly without using the mouse. They save time and make your work faster and easier.

Examples:
âœ… Ctrl + C â€“ Copy
âœ… Ctrl + V â€“ Paste
âœ… Ctrl + X â€“ Cut
âœ… Ctrl + S â€“ Save
âœ… Alt + Tab â€“ Switch between windows

Benefits:
ğŸ‘‰ Work faster
ğŸ‘‰ Reduce mouse use
ğŸ‘‰ Look like a computer pro!

Practice Tip: Try learning one new shortcut every day.

lessons.title: Home and End Keys
lessons.content:
The Home and End keys help you move quickly when typing or reading on your computer. They are usually found near the arrow keys on your keyboard.


ğŸ’» What They Do:

  • Home Key â€“ When typing in a line of text, pressing Home takes your cursor to the beginning of that line.
  • End Key â€“ Moves your cursor to the end of the line you are typing.

ğŸ“˜ Examples:

  • If you are writing: â€œI love computers.â€ and your cursor is at the end, press Home to jump back to the â€˜Iâ€™ quickly.
  • Press End to jump from the beginning of a sentence to the last word instantly.

ğŸ”€ When Used with Other Keys:

  • Ctrl + Home â€“ Moves to the very beginning of a document or webpage.
  • Ctrl + End â€“ Moves to the very end of a document or webpage.

In short: The Home and End keys help you move around your text or page faster, saving time and effort while typing!

lessons.title: Arrow Keys
lessons.content:
The Arrow Keys are the four keys that point Up, Down, Left, and Right. They help you move around on your computer without using the mouse.


ğŸ® What They Do:

  • Up Arrow (â†‘) â€“ Moves the cursor or object upward.
  • Down Arrow (â†“) â€“ Moves the cursor or object downward.
  • Left Arrow (â†) â€“ Moves the cursor or object to the left.
  • Right Arrow (â†’) â€“ Moves the cursor or object to the right.

ğŸ§  Common Uses:

  • Scroll up or down in a document or webpage.
  • Move a character in computer games.
  • Navigate cells in a table or spreadsheet.

Tip: Combine arrow keys with Shift to select text or items in a list.

lessons.title: Control Keys (Ctrl)
lessons.content:
The Control key (Ctrl) is used together with other keys to perform quick commands called keyboard shortcuts. There are usually two Ctrl keys on a keyboard â€“ one on the left and one on the right.


âœ¨ Common Ctrl Shortcuts:

  • Ctrl + A â€“ Selects all text or items.
  • Ctrl + B â€“ Makes selected text bold.
  • Ctrl + C â€“ Copies the selected item.
  • Ctrl + V â€“ Pastes what you copied.
  • Ctrl + X â€“ Cuts the selected text or file.
  • Ctrl + Z â€“ Undo the last action (go back one step).
  • Ctrl + S â€“ Save your work.
  • Ctrl + P â€“ Print the document.
  • Ctrl + F â€“ Find a word in a document or webpage.

In short: The Ctrl key helps you work faster by combining it with letters for powerful shortcuts.

lessons.title: Shift Key
lessons.content:
The Shift key is used to type capital letters and special symbols. You can find two Shift keys on your keyboard, one on each side.


ğŸ“ Uses of the Shift Key:

  • Capital Letters: Hold Shift and press a letter key to type a capital letter (Example: Shift + a = A).
  • Symbols: Hold Shift to type the upper symbols on number keys. (Example: Shift + 2 = @).
  • Highlight Text: Use Shift + Arrow Keys to select text without using a mouse.

In short: The Shift key changes what other keys do, helping you type neatly and accurately!

lessons.title: Number Keys
lessons.content:
The Number Keys are the keys with numbers 0â€“9. You can find them above the letter keys and also on the numeric keypad (on some keyboards).


ğŸ” Uses of Number Keys:

  • Type numbers in your documents, forms, and games.
  • When used with Shift, they type special symbols. Example: Shift + 1 = !, Shift + 2 = @, Shift + 3 = #, and so on.

Fun fact: The numeric keypad on the right side helps you type numbers faster â€” just like a calculator!
